content.description: This is a great route for beginners and a good place to take people here who are new to bouldering. It is pretty high, but its easy and pretty fun. Start on holds at about chest height and climb up to a big sharp skinny flake and then top out.
content.location:
This is just to the right of

South Undercling

.

content.description:
As described on flagstaffmountainbouldering.blogspot.com

"Climb straight up the face past the obvious horizontal crack with a good undercling."

This problem was the biggest learning curve I've ever encountered. I'm not sure who rated it V3, but I've seen people who power through V6s and 7s walk away defeated here. Don't be mislead by its low rating is all I have to offer.
content.location: This is left of The Amphitheater proper, through the undercling. You can't miss it, it's right on the trail.

content.description: Super classic Flag Favorite.  In the [Amphitheatre] Right Wall are slots from head heigth (middle left) up and right to jug system at top. Worth it just for the top out! So fun and a long overdue addition to the website.

On the high left side of the amphitheater, tunnel underneath an overhang to a short very undercut bulge. This is Mongolian Cosmonaut. Start low with the right in an OK pocket/edge and the left on a pebbly cluster under the bulge. Punch up and left to a sloper then up crimps and pebbles to the top. Fun moves, solid rock,safe landing. There is  a true sit start (John Stack FA?) at likely V12 that starts with the small pebble cluster for the L and an undercling on a pebble low and right. Jump for the pocket and continue.
content.protection: Crashpad or two to pad adjacent boulders.

content.description:
Start on top of the boulder separating

Mongolian Cosmonaut

from the amphitheater proper. SDS (if you're tall) with your right hand on the large, sidepull pebble and your left hand on the textured, bulging, crimp rail.  Follow the line of cobbles and edges left, and finish the same as

Mongolian Cosmonaut

.
content.location:
Start on top of the boulder immediately right of

Mongolian Cosmonaut

.

content.description: Long reaches are mandatory on this problem.
content.location: In the middle of the flat face and six feet left of sandpaper ledge are small edges that lead to a jug complex.

content.description: Go up the east-facing crack via some good holds to a jug around the corner. Then downclimb the other side (the front of the Amphitheater).
content.protection: A couple of pads. It's a bit high, and the landing is sloping.
content.location:
This is on the main, lower amphitheater block (same as

Gill Direct

). It is the first route you see when coming up from the Red Wall, just around the corner from

The Direct Route

.

content.description:
This is also known as Sandpaper Ledge.

Climb the overhanging wall on the far right side of the Amphitheater. Climb to the sloping (sandpaper) hold in the middle of the face and then straight up. Mantel at the lip, and then solo up left on the low angle slab and arête.

Aerial Shoot dynos from the sandpaper hold to the upper holds - FA Dan Stone, 1979.
